content.title: What is a Tangent?
content.body:
A tangent to a circle is a line that intersects the circle at only **one** point. 

- The point where the line touches the circle is called the **point of contact**.
- There is only one tangent at a single point of the circle.
- There are no tangents from a point inside the circle.
content.analogy: Imagine a bicycle wheel rolling on flat ground. The ground is a tangent to the wheel, touching it at exactly one point at any given moment.

content.instruction: This is the foundation for solving circle geometry problems:
content.exactPhrase: The tangent at any point of a circle is perpendicular to the radius through the point of contact. (i.e., radius \(\perp\) tangent).

content.instruction: This theorem is frequently asked as a 3-mark proof:
content.exactPhrase: The lengths of tangents drawn from an external point to a circle are equal. If PA and PB are tangents from point P to a circle, then \(PA = PB\).

content.instruction: Memorize this relationship for 2-mark angle-finding questions:
content.exactPhrase: The angle between the two tangents drawn from an external point to a circle is supplementary to the angle subtended by the line-segment joining the points of contact at the centre.

content.question: How many tangents can be drawn to a circle from a point lying outside the circle?
content.explanation: From any point outside a circle, exactly two tangents can be drawn. From a point *on* the circle, only one can be drawn. From *inside*, none can be drawn.

content.hook: Radius meets Tangent at a Right angle
content.explanation: Think of 'RT' (Radio-Tangent) = **R**ight **T**riangle. Whenever a radius hits a tangent, a \(90^\circ\) angle is born!
